newsitem.title: JAPAN: Top metal trader Hamanaka seen as quiet family man.
newsitem.headline: Top metal trader Hamanaka seen as quiet family man.

text.p: To the financial world, Yasuo Hamanaka was a feared player in the world copper market who became the key figure in the biggest financial scandal in history.
But to neighbours and friends he was a quiet family man whose demeanour belied the huge funds he once controlled as a top trader.
On Tuesday, Tokyo prosecutors arrested Hamanaka, who is 48, on charges that he forged documents to create secret trading accounts for manipulation of the world copper market.

Sumitomo, a financial powerhouse, rocked world markets on June 13 when it announced it had fired Hamanaka, saying he had run up record losses of $1.8 billion on unauthorised trades that went on for more than a decade.
As copper prices collapsed after the scandal was announced, the company said in September that the losses had grown to $2.6 billion.
"Sumitomo is currently placing the blame only on him, but I can't believe their story at face value," a source close to the family said as the affair unfolded last summer.
While high-rolling traders were common in the financial world, especially during the boom years of the 1980s, Hamanaka did not fit the image.
His two-storey house in the city of Kawasaki, on the outskirts of Tokyo, has nothing to distinguish it in a neighbourhood populated by mid-level office workers rather than financial superstars.
"Mr Hamanaka would sometimes walk his dog around the neighbourhood during the weekend. He looked just like any other quiet salaried worker," a neighbour said.
"I never realised he was such a world famous metal trader."

Neighbours say he drove a mid-range Nissan, eschewing the flashy BMWs beloved by high-profile traders worldwide. To commute, he crowded on to packed railway trains each morning like millions of other Japanese workers.
And in common with many Japanese workers, Hamanaka spent his entire career with one company.
Unusually, though, he spent 21 of his 26 years there trading in copper. Traders are usually shifted regularly from one section to another to keep them fresh.
"He sometimes took weekend drives with his family and was a real family man. I'm so worried about his family after the copper scandal," the neighbour said.

Hamanaka once berated a Reuters reporter for calling him at home with a question about the copper market. "It's OK to press me for any comment on the market in the office, but never get my family involved," he said.
Hamanaka began his career in 1970 after graduating from Tokyo's Seikei University, a private university that is popular but not especially prestigious.
He and his wife have two children, a high-school-age son and a daughter who has just started work after graduating from university.
